text: as the Sun Goes Down we set out with the
Tripoli Coast Guard facing the perils of
the Mediterranean which has claimed so
many this inflatable battered by the
waves is their only seaworthy vessel
from their fleet of four three need
repairs later in pitch darkness they're
on the lookout for migrants in distress
not easy without night-vision goggles
all they can do is listen for their
vessels it's half 1:00 in the morning
and we're in a stretch of water where
smugglers boats pass regularly usually
between one and three now the engine is
off here the lights are off the Coast
Guard don't want to alert anyone to
their presence but if a rescue is needed
here tonight they have just this one
small vessel with daybreak no trouble on
the horizon this time but they say it's
the traffickers who rule the waves
smugglers have more boats and more
weapons they have long range guns they
can esker the migrants to European
waters and we can't do anything to stop
them the state doesn't support us we
haven't been paid since March and Coast
Guard officials say there's another
problem farther out to sea
just beyond Libyan territorial waters
operations Sofia
they say the EU mission supposed to
disrupt smuggling is ferrying migrants
to Italy like a taxi there's agreement
from a smuggler
now detained who the authorities say is
a big fish the operational sieve life
and courage to put to travel more the
rescue they are very close to Libya so
they think these ships will pick them up
quickly quickly here when you were
arranging for these people to get on
these overcrowded boats and go to Europe
did you ever stop to think that they
could die on the way whoa
no because we always pray for them you
know but here's how they send them to
see the Coast Guard coming to rescue
this overloaded vessel last month
pregnant women among those scrambling
for places and this is what awaits those
saved by the Coast Guard detention back
in Libya even for women and children the
youngest not spared Mahmoud is just 21
days old several of those here told us
they wouldn't risk the crossing again
but the Coast Guard say they have
rescued some migrants five or six times
for the men and boys even worse
conditions the authorities say they're
doing their best with scarce resources
amidst the chaos of Libya this 14 year
old from Gambia told us his brother was
caught and deported in 2010 still he
came here all alone hoping to find work
in Europe many we met were economic
migrants trapped in what amounts to a
teeming prison we also had the same two
toilets two toilets we have here that we
see a four hundreds of people you have
four hundreds of people under the same
roof here it's really unnormal here we
have here three months and my other
fellow Gambians are four months here
some are on the move more than a hundred
and sixty men heading to the airport
instead of the new life they craved
being deported back to Gambia others
like Betty from Nigeria are still
eagerly waiting to cross the
Mediterranean my children they don't
need to suffer like me that is why I
need to go to hotel me things are no
hesitate so I know who is more better
than Nigeria my children need to go to
school they need to have a better life
Betty knows some who set out from here
wash up on the beaches but she says her
only chance of a new life is to risk
death at sea
Orla Garin BBC News Tripoli
